section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (howled, plans).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How do people work together to build something?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing concept words and main characters.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Persist in tasks.
Recognize own written name.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, such as food, clothing, and shelter.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Gather sand, scoop, and papers with children’s names.
Invite children to dig out letters to spell out their names.
Invite children to say and write their own names, and to talk about their names.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you name some books about building? What are their titles?
Can you pretend that you are building a house? Show how you will make the walls. How will you reach the roof?
Think about shapes. If you were building a house, what shape would you make the windows? How about the doors?
Write about what kind of house you would build for a pet.
Can you draw plans for a house for a pet?
What name can you give a pet that starts with the same first letter as your name?
Can you build a house for a tiny pet? How will you build it?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss the Mind Builder persist in tasks and introduce vocabulary (ideas, complete).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Little Red Fort.
Read to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Persist in tasks.
Write own name.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, such as food, clothing, and shelter.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Use simple tools to measure and learn.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to make forts out of wooden blocks.
Encourage children to try a different design for their fort.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What does Ruby want to build?
Act out how you would ask someone to help you build something.
What would you do if your boards were too long? How would you change them?
Can you write about something you would change in your house?
Can you make plans for what you would change in your house?
Can you use your arm and hand to draw the first letter of your first name in the air?
Can you build something that is the same size as your foot?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier, illustrated by Sonia Sánchez. Text copyright © 2018 by Brenda Maier. section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Make a Connection and introduce vocabulary (gather, supplies).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How can working with others help you solve problems?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, discussing solving problems.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Persist in tasks.
Write own name.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Use simple tools to measure and learn about different objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to look at pictures of different supplies in the book and tell if Ruby used them to build her fort.
Encourage children to talk about how Ruby used the supplies.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you think of books that tell stories about people working together?
Act out how you would work with an adult to cut boards.
Why do you need to measure things? What can you use to measure?
Can you write a list of things you would need to build a tree house?
Can you draw a plan for a tree house?
What will you call your tree house? What is the first letter of the name of your tree house?
Can you build a small tree house for a mouse?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier, illustrated by Sonia Sánchez. Text copyright © 2018 by Brenda Maier. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Sonia Sánchez. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Three Little Rabbits

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a story located on the Big Chart, and introduce vocabulary (straw, sticks).
Begin Story Time by introducing The Three Little Rabbits and reading the story.
Differentiate by using images to scaffold text.
Read for enjoyment and understanding, pointing out familiar literature connections.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand and uses a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Persist in tasks.
Write own name.
Show understanding that people have basic needs, such as food, clothing, and shelter.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Use simple tools to measure and learn about different objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to look at pictures of items made of different materials and guess what the material is.
Review straw and sticks Vocabulary Cards.
Talk about the qualities of different materials.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Compare a house made of straw and a house made of bricks. Which one is stronger?
Act out being very strong. What will you do?
Draw a picture of your family. Is anyone bigger than you? Is anyone smaller than you?
Can you write about a time that you built something?
Draw or paint a picture of a house you would like to live in. Be creative and use many different materials. For instance, your house might have a glass tower or a wall made of growing plants.
What letter looks most like a house to you? Can you write it?
Can you build a tiny house? What materials would you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Little Red Fort by Brenda Maier, illustrated by Sonia Sánchez. Text copyright © 2018 by Brenda Maier. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Sonia Sánchez. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children with a story and introduce vocabulary (huddled, delicious).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How can working together make it easier to build something?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Persist in tasks.
Cooperate and work as a team toward a shared goal.
Recognize own written name.
Write own name.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How can working together make building easier?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Look for another book that shows people or animals building something. What are they building?
Pretend you completed building something. What would you do to celebrate?
If you build something together with a friend, how many hands will there be to build? (Hint: you have two and your friend has two.)
Imagine you are having a party in your fort. Can you write an invitation to the party?
Can you draw a picture for your invitation?
Can you write your name on the invitation?
Can you build an activity to play at your party?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Write own name (first name or frequent nickname) using legible letters in proper sequence.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Use simple measuring devices to learn about objects.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Write own name (first name or frequent nickname) using legible letters in proper sequence.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use simple measuring devices to learn about objects.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Use simple measuring devices to learn about objects.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding new words daily.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Write own name (first name or frequent nickname) using legible letters in proper sequence.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
